variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning aviation safety culture is correct?

options.text: An informed culture actively collects, analyses and distributes safety-related data.
In a flexible culture, committed errors can be voiced without risking negative consequences for oneself.
In an open culture, the highest good is the cumulative well-being of the society as a whole.
A just culture is a culture in which errors made in flight are never prosecuted in order to encourage pilots to openly communicate them.

variant.question: Consider aviation as a safety culture. Responsibility for safety lies with the?
A First Officer forgots to switch the anti-icing off after leaving icing conditions. The Captain realises this and yells at the FO for it. What type of culture is the Captain portraying?
The rate of accidents in commercial aviation (excluding sabotage and acts of terrorism)

options.text: is approximatively 1 accident per million airport movements.
is a long way short of the safety level of road transport.
has improved considerably over the last fifteen years.
represents about fifty accidents around the world every year.

variant.question: During the flight the captain realises that the first-officer forgot to turn the anti-ice on, so he gets angry and starts yelling at the him/her. How would you describe the culture of this behaviour?
The culture of the Aviation Authority is regarded as:

A passenger aircraft approaches its destination and starts its descent. A passenger experiences an increasing pain in the ears and advises the cabin crew of his problem. What would be a proper first reaction of the cabin crew?

options.text: Instruct the passenger to make swallowing or chewing movements.
Call the cockpit and ask the pilots to maintain altitude or climb.
Offering the passenger adequate pain relief medication from the first aid kit.
Supply the affected passenger with bottled oxygen.

variant.question: Macho attitude is manifested in a pilot with

options.text: an excessively high opinion of him/herself.
a tendency to avoid making difficult decisions.
a resentment of being told what to do.
an urge to do something impulsively.

variant.question: Pilots on the flight deck, with a "macho attitude", tend to...

options.text: have a very high opinion of themselves.
dislike if others tell them what to do.
avoid making decisions which are difficult.

variant.question: The team spirit of a cockpit-crew depends most likely on both pilots:

options.text: respecting each other and striving for the same goals
having the same political and ideological attitude
flying together very often for a long period

variant.question: An under-confident and unassuming First Officer is promoted to Captain. Such a person could exhibit a behavioural pattern which is..

options.text: characterised by an outward show of aggression and self-assertiveness.
successfully altered by the training programme’s focus on leadership qualities.
marked by moments of self-doubt, occasionally leading to depression.
influenced by the new role and publicly exhibits respect and competence.

variant.question: Which of the following personality characteristics makes crew decision making most effective?

A student pilot has failed an important flight test and examination. With help from a positive instructor, the student eventually completes training and passes the flight test.
The effect of the experience on the student is:

options.text: A student with a stable personality will be able to realise that sometimes things do not go perfectly and learn from the experience.
A student with a stable personality will have a lower self-confidence afterwards.
The experience will heavily affect the student. He will have poor self-confidence afterwards and frequently require reassurance from others.
The experience will markedly boost the student’s self-confidence as he realises that he can achieve everything with sufficient training.

variant.question: Analysis of accidents involving the human factor in aviation shows that

options.text: there is hardly ever a single cause responsible.
failure of the human factor is always connected with technical breakdowns.
only pilot training will make it possible to improve the situation.

variant.question: In a cockpit culture with a steep power gradient, how would a copilot respond to his superior if he thought a decision was poor?

options.text: He would generally not question his superior.
He would always question his superior.
He would never question his superior.
He would generally question his superior.

variant.question:
A helicopter pilot under supervision working for a medical evacuation team performs a landing without keeping to mandatory airspeed and height values at the landing decision point, and without actively engaging in the recommended crew concept.
The supervising captain then conducts a debriefing of the manoeuvre, and points out the various deficiencies. The pilot reacts by stating that he/she is an excellent pilot who is without any doubt capable of performing such manoeuvres safely.
What of these hazardous attitudes best fits the attitude of the pilot under supervision?

An ATO which is rather lax when it comes to complying with rules and regulations forms a young pilot. After his graduation, the pilot gets hired by an airline which strictly complies with all legal requirements. Which kind of behaviour will the young pilot show?

options.text: At first, he will stick to the behavioural patterns he has learned in his flight school and will then adapt to the more restrictive behaviour of his company’s pilots.
The pilot will be overly correct when starting his new job and then gradually return to the attitude he obtained in flight training.
He will carefully make sure to comply with all legal requirements from his first day.
He will likely never begin to strictly observe rules and procedures and develop a laissez-faire attitude.

variant.question: What human attitudes have been found to be particularly hazardous to aviation?

options.text: Anti-authority, impulsivity, invulnerability, macho, resignation, complacency.
Anti-authority, macho, invulnerability, complacency, co-operative, impulsivity.
Impulsivity, irascibility, complacency, anti-authority, resignation, invulnerability.

variant.question: A copilot notices that the captain has missed an item on a checklist. When he mentions this, the captain replies: “Don’t tell me what to do”. The type of behaviour shown be the captain is...

options.text: A personality trait, which cannot be fixed.

variant.question: Motivation, crew-climate and Confirmation Bias are factors that

options.text: depend only on personality and are unchangeable.

variant.question: Which of the following is not a hazardous attitude?

A helicopter pilot is performing a landing and on short final he/she is not keeping the mandatory airspeed and heights. At debriefing, his/her commander pointed out what he/she did not follow the operating standards. The pilot roughly said that he/she is a good pilot and is very good at flying. What kind of attitude is this?
A number of pilots subconsciously believe that accidents can only happen to others and never to themselves. What is this type of attitude called?

A number of pilots subconsciously believe that accidents can only happen to others and never to themselves.
What is this type of attitude called?
What is the name of the following hazardous attitude: “Accidents can only happen to others”?
<div>Resignation is a dangerous attitude because it:

options.text: <div class="WordSection1">Lowers the self-confidence of the affected flight crew member.
Makes the non-affected flight crew member spend less time anticipating future actions.
Makes the affected flight crew member more likely to show impulsive behaviour.
<div class="WordSection1">Makes the affected flight crew member feel more hopeful of a positive outcome.

variant.question: The ATO attended by an ab-initio pilot operates with a relaxed, non-punitive culture, and the flight instructors often make minor violations in standard procedures and safety. The pilot successfully completes training and starts to fly for a major Operator. What influence is the ATO's culture most likely to have on the pilot's behaviour when flying for the Operator?

options.text: The attitude and behaviour of the pilot at first will reflect the culture of the ATO, but will change with time to the more disciplined environment of the Operator.
The pilot, on completion of training, will disregard the culture of the ATO and immediately change to a more disciplined type of behaviour.
The culture of the ATO has very little or NO influence on the behaviour of the pilot because he/she has successfully completed the training.
Regardless of his/her personality and attitude, the culture of the ATO encourages the pilot to take risks, and this behaviour is resistant to change with time.

variant.question: A copilot got hired by a renowned company for a short-term contract. Approaching the end of his contract, he learns that only one spot will be available for a subsequent contract with two copilots competing for continuation of their employment. The copilot shows a high motivation. What should a commander flying with this copilot pay particular attention to?

options.text: It can be assumed that the copilot is under pressure to perform, because he feels that any mistake could cause his employer to give the vacant spot to his competitor at the end of the contract. The commander should aim to remove some of the pressure by reassuring the copilot that his work is highly appreciated.
The commander should tell the copilot that he is aware of his possibly increased basic stress level and demand clearly that the copilot keep all his personal emotions out of the cockpit.

It is the commander’s responsibility to assist his employer in deciding on the better copilot for continuation of the contract. He should therefore closely monitor the copilot’s work and report any errors or insecurities to his superior without the copilot noticing.

The commander should be aware that the copilot will probably feel a lower desire to perform, because the end of his contract is approaching and he may not be working for the company for very long. The commander should remind the copilot that any deterioration in performance will not be tolerated.

variant.question: What is characterized by a laissez-faire cockpit?

options.text: A passive approach by the captain allows decisions, choices and actions by other crew members.
Each member carries out actions and makes choices without explicitly informing the other members about them.
The high level of independence granted to each member by the captain quickly leads to tension between the various crew members.
The captain's authority rules all the actions or decisions associated with the situation.

variant.question: Which of the following responses lists most of the common hazardous thought patterns (attitudes) for pilots to develop?

options.text: Anti-authority, impulsiveness, invulnerability, resignation, machismo complex.
Machismo complex, resignation, confidence, self criticism.
Invulnerability, under-confidence, avoidance of making decisions, lack of situational awareness.

variant.question: How would you describe the leadership style of a captain who primarily is interested in a friendly atmosphere within his crew, who is always constructive and encouraging, who usually compromises in interpersonal conflicts, who trusts in the capabilities of his crew-members, and who leaves the crew freedom for own decisions?
Informal roles within a crew:

options.text: evolve as a result of the interactions that take place among crew members.
are explicitly set out by the crew.
do not impair the captain's influence.

variant.question: Which behavioural traits in pilots pose the greatest hazard for flight safety?

What are the most frequent and the least appropriate reactions on the part of a co-pilot when faced with a highly authoritarian captain?
1) Self-assertion.
2) A scapegoat feeling.
3) Delayed reactions to observed discrepancies.
4) Disengagement.
What behavioural traits have been found to be particularly hazardous to aviation?

options.text: Anti-authority, impulsivity, invulnerability, macho, resignation,  complacency.
Impulsivity, irascibility, complacency, anti-authority, resignation, invulnerability.
Anti-authority, macho, invulnerability, complacency, co-operative, impulsivity.

variant.question: A pilot meets the ground engineer in charge on the apron. Although the pilot has not been through flight preparation yet, he nevertheless instructs the engineer as to the amount of fuel to be loaded, since he is used to flying this route. This behaviour results from:

options.text: A decision bias due to habits (frequency bias)
A decision bias due to group (social) pressure

variant.question: A pilot meets the ground engineer in charge on the apron. Although the pilot has not been through flight preparation yet, he nevertheless instructs the engineer as to the amount of fuel to be loaded, since he is used to flying this route. This behaviour represents:

options.text: a decision bias due to habits (frequency bias).
a decision bias due to group (social) pressure.

variant.question: What attributes would apply to the personality of an ideal crew member?
A pilot has difficulties making difficult decisions. Which hazardous attitude could be a cause for this?
"It will not happen to me", can be used as an example to illustrate which attitude?

As a first officer you are flying with a captain. During the beginning of the flight, the captain starts asking you several questions to test your knowledge. As soon as you answer a question wrongly, the captain humiliates you. From this moment you feel isolated from the flight. During the approach, the captain instructs you to enter non-standard waypoints but you know that those entries are wrong. You decide to do what the captain told you to do. This type of behaviour you have shown refers to...
